summary: Myelofibrosis is a rare bone marrow blood cancer classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It involves the remodeling of bone marrow with osteosclerosis and the secretion of collagen and reticulin proteins (fibrosis), which compromise normal bone marrow function and lead to decreased production of blood cells like erythrocytes, granulocytes, and platelets. It can also be a complication of other myeloproliferative disorders like polycythemia vera and essential thrombocythemia.
causes: Somatic mutation in JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes
risk_factors: Previous myeloproliferative disorders (polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia)
symptoms: Cachexia (loss of appetite, weight loss, fatigue)
Leukoerythroblastic smear (tear-drop RBCs, nucleated RBCs, immature granulocytes)
diagnosis: Physical exam of the abdomen (for enlarged spleen or liver)
